qas.question: What do all living humans belong to?
Race has no taxonomic significance among whom?
What set of traits do some scientists use race to make distinctions among?
How do scientists around the world continue to conceptualize race?

context: Even though there is a broad scientific agreement that essentialist and typological conceptualizations of race are untenable, scientists around the world continue to conceptualize race <a4_0>in widely differing ways<a4_0/>, some of which have essentialist implications. While some researchers sometimes use the concept of race to make distinctions among <a3_0>fuzzy<a3_0/> sets of traits, others in the scientific community suggest that the idea of race often is used in a naive or simplistic way,[page needed] and argue that, among <a2_0>humans<a2_0/>, race has no taxonomic significance by pointing out that all living humans belong to <a0_0>the same species<a0_0/>, <a1_0>Homo sapiens<a1_0/>, and subspecies, Homo sapiens sapiens.
